questions.text: A 15-year-old female is brought to the OPD by her mother for evaluation as she has been eating very little and becoming very thin. O/E: her BMI <17.5, Russell's sign was seen. Mother is reporting that she is indulging in rigorous exercises and over-gymming. During the interview, the girl is irritated and says that she is doing good and eating fine. On further enquiry, it was found that she hasn't had menses for the last 3 months. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

The patient has a BMI <17.5, amenorrhea for 3 months, rigorous exercise, and denies her illness-all hallmark features of anorexia nervosa.

The presence of Russell's sign, although more classically seen in bulimia, supports the presence of compensatory behavior (e.g., purging), fitting the binge-eating/purging type of anorexia.

Core Features:

  • Persistent restriction of energy intake, leading to significantly low body weight.
  • Intense fear of gaining weight or persistent behavior interfering with weight gain.
  • Distorted body image, denial of the seriousness of low body weight.

Subtypes:

  • Restricting Type: Weight loss through dieting, fasting, or exercise.
  • Binge-eating/Purging Type: Includes episodes of binge eating or purging (vomiting, laxatives, etc.).

Physical Signs:

  • BMI <17.5
  • Amenorrhea (due to hypothalamic suppression)
  • Lanugo, dry skin, bradycardia
  • Hyperactivity (compulsive exercise)
  • Russell's sign (calluses from self-induced vomiting)
  • Electrolyte abnormalities in purging type

Psychiatric Profile:

  • Often perfectionistic, rigid, and denies the problem
  • Irritable or withdrawn during interviews
  • Poor insight

Explanation of Other Options:

Bulimia Nervosa (Option A): Involves binge eating followed by purging, but weight is usually normal or slightly overweight. Does not usually present with a BMI <17.5 or amenorrhea. Patients are often distressed by their behavior and are more willing to seek help.

Pica (Option C): Characterized by eating non-food, non-nutritive substances (e.g., dirt, paper) for >1 month. Has no link with body image, exercise, or weight concern.

Binge Eating Disorder (Option D): Repeated episodes of binge eating without compensatory behaviors. Typically results in overweight or obesity, not weight loss or amenorrhea. Not associated with excessive exercise or distorted body image to the extent seen in anorexia.

questions.text: The differentiating feature of avoidant restrictive food intake disorder and restrictive type of anorexia nervosa is:
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

The absence of body image disturbance is what distinguishes Avoidant/Restrictive Food Intake Disorder (ARFID) from Anorexia Nervosa (Restrictive Type).

Explanation of Other Options:

Weight loss is seen (Option A): True for both ARFID and Anorexia Nervosa, so not differentiating.

Nutritional deficiencies (Option B): Common in both disorders, especially in prolonged cases.

Insufficient intake of food (Option D): Again, seen in both. It is the reason behind it that differs.

questions.text: Which of the following questionnaire systems is used for eating disorders?
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

The SCOFF is a simple and validated screening tool used to identify eating disorders like anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa, particularly in primary care settings.

Each letter stands for one key screening question:

Interpretation: 2 or more "Yes" answers warrant further evaluation for an eating disorder.

Explanation of other options:

CAGE (Option A): Screening tool for alcohol dependence, asking about Cut down, Annoyed, Guilty, Eye-opener.

M-CHAT (Modified Checklist for Autism in Toddlers) (Option B): Used to screen Autism Spectrum Disorders in toddlers aged 16-30 months.

AUDIT (Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test) (Option D): A 10-item questionnaire developed by WHO to assess alcohol consumption, drinking behaviors, and alcohol-related problems.

choices.text: Weight for height less than 75% of normal

questions.text: Hospitalized management of anorexia nervosa is done on priority in patients with:
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

The first and foremost step in treating anorexia nervosa is restoration of nutritional status, as starvation, dehydration, and electrolyte imbalance can be life-threatening.

  • Inpatient psychiatric treatment is required when a patient is ≥ 30% below expected body weight, i.e., < 70% of ideal weight.
  • Inpatient programs (not necessarily psychiatric) are needed when the weight is ≥ 20% below normal, i.e., < 80% of expected weight.
  • Psychiatric hospitalization for 2-6 months is often warranted when the weight is < 70-75% of the ideal body weight.
  • Therefore, weight for height less than 75% of normal is an appropriate clinical threshold that necessitates hospitalization to prevent complications or death.

Other indications for hospitalization include:

  • Rapid or continued weight loss despite outpatient treatment
  • Severe electrolyte imbalance (e.g., hypokalemia)
  • Bradycardia, hypotension, or hypothermia
  • Acute food refusal
  • Suicidality or severe psychiatric comorbidity
  • Failure to respond to outpatient therapy

Explanation of other options:

Depression (Option A): Although often comorbid, depression alone does not mandate hospitalization unless there's suicidality or functional decompensation.

Amenorrhea (Option B): Previously a DSM-IV criterion, now no longer required for diagnosis in DSM-5, and is not a reason for admission.

Binging episodes (Option C): Suggestive of bulimia nervosa or binge-purge subtype of anorexia; may need treatment but doesn't independently necessitate hospitalization unless associated with severe medical compromise.

questions.text: A 23-year-old college student comes to the physician because her roommates are worried about her eating. She tells the physician that she regularly eats large amounts of food(more than 10,000 calories on occasion) and then has to 'punish herself' and 'get rid of it'. She explains that she does this by sticking her finger down her throat, which causes her to vomit. She tried to hide this activity from her roommates, but on more than one occasion, they have heard her retching in the bathroom. The patient is 5'5" tall and weighs 132 lb. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

The patient presents with repeated episodes of binge eating (consuming >10,000 calories) followed by purging behavior(self-induced vomiting) to avoid weight gain. Her normal BMI excludes anorexia nervosa, confirming the diagnosis of bulimia nervosa.

Bulimia nervosa is characterized by recurrent episodes of binge eating followed by inappropriate compensatory behaviors (e.g., vomiting, laxatives, excessive exercise) to prevent weight gain.

Clinical features:

  • Binge eating episodes: Repeated episodes (at least once a week for 3 months) of eating an unusually large amount of food within a short period, accompanied by a loss of control during the episode.
  • Compensatory behaviors: Recurrent inappropriate behaviors to prevent weight gain, such as self-induced vomiting, laxative misuse, fasting, or excessive exercise.
  • Body image disturbance: Self-worth is excessively influenced by body shape and weight.
  • Not exclusively during anorexia nervosa: The individual is not underweight, which differentiates bulimia from anorexia nervosa.

Epidemiology & Course:

  • More common in females, especially adolescents and young adults.
  • Patients are usually of normal weight or slightly overweight.
  • Associated with impulsivity, substance abuse, and mood disorders.
  • The course is often chronic, with periods of remission and relapse.

Complications:

  • Electrolyte disturbances (hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis).
  • Parotid gland hypertrophy, dental erosion.
  • Mallory-Weiss tears, Russell's sign (calluses on knuckles).

Treatment:

  • Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) is first-line.
  • SSRIs, especially fluoxetine, help reduce binge-purge cycles.
  • Hospitalization if suicidal ideation or severe electrolyte imbalance is present.

Explanation of Other Options:

Anorexia Nervosa (Option A): Significantly low BMI (<17.5), intense fear of gaining weight, and body image distortion. In this case, the patient's BMI is normal, making anorexia unlikely.

Avoidant/Restrictive Food Intake Disorder (ARFID) (Option B): No binging or purging. Seen more in children. Avoids food due to taste/smell or fear of choking-not body image-related.

Binge-Eating Disorder (BED) (Option C): Recurrent binge eating without compensatory behaviors (no purging or exercise). Patients are usually overweight or obese.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with a 10-year history of episodes in which she eats large quantities of food, such as eight hamburgers and three quarts of ice cream, at a single sitting. Because of her intense feelings of guilt, she then repeatedly induces vomiting. This cycle repeats itself several times a week. She is extremely ashamed of her behaviour but says, "I can't stop doing it". On examination, which of the following physical findings is most likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

This woman meets the criteria for bulimia nervosa:

  • Recurrent binge eating (e.g., 8 hamburgers + 3 quarts of ice cream at once),
  • Recurrent compensatory behavior (self-induced vomiting),
  • Guilt and lack of control over the behavior,
  • Normal or near-normal weight, unlike anorexia.

Frequent vomiting in bulimia exposes the teeth to gastric acid, which causes enamel erosion and leads to dental caries. Other oral complications may include:

  • Perimolysis (acid erosion of enamel),
  • Enlarged parotid glands (round face),
  • Calluses on knuckles or fingers (Russell's sign).

Explanation of Other Options:

Lanugo (Option B): Fine body hair seen in anorexia nervosa as a response to hypothermia from starvation.

Muscle wasting (Option C): A feature of severe malnutrition, also seen in anorexia, not typical of bulimia, since most patients are within the normal weight range.

Alopecia (Option D): Can occur with nutritional deficiencies, but it's more strongly associated with chronic starvation, as in anorexia.

questions.text: A 17-year-old adolescent suffers from Bulimia nervosa and is very depressed. She is also suffering from insomnia and apathy. Which of the following medications should be avoided?
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

This 17-year-old has bulimia nervosa and symptoms of depression (insomnia, apathy). While antidepressants are often helpful, bupropion should be avoided in this case.

  • Bupropion is a norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitor (NDRI).
  • It is contraindicated in patients with eating disorders, especially bulimia nervosa.
  • It lowers the seizure threshold, and individuals with bulimia are already at increased risk of seizures, particularly due to electrolyte disturbances from vomiting and purging.
  • Additionally, it has anorectic (appetite-suppressing) properties, which may worsen disordered eating behaviors.

Explanation of other options:

Fluoxetine (Option A): First-line SSRI approved for the treatment of bulimia nervosa. It helps reduce binge-purge cycles and improve mood.

Trazodone (Option B): An antidepressant with strong sedative properties; sometimes used for insomnia in depressed patients. It does not lower the seizure threshold significantly.

Amitriptyline (Option D): A tricyclic antidepressant (TCA); though not first-line due to anticholinergic side effects and overdose risk, it's not contraindicated like bupropion.

choices.text: Complete blood count and differential white blood cell count
Calculation and assessment of patient BMI

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to a physician by her mother, who states that her daughter has been losing weight steadily. The adolescent denies there is a problem and states that she is in no way underweight. The physician determines that the girl is 5 ft 6 in tall and weighs 90 lbs. Which of the following would be the next best step to work this patient up?
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

  • This 16-year-old girl shows clear risk factors for anorexia nervosa: significant weight loss, denial of the problem, and distorted body image.
  • At 5'6" (167.6 cm) and 90 lbs (40.8 kg), her BMI is approximately 14.5, which is well below normal.
  • Calculating BMI is a quick, non-invasive, and essential screening tool for diagnosing eating disorders in adolescents.
  • It also helps determine the urgency of intervention (e.g., hospitalization if <80% of expected weight).

Explanation of other options:

CBC (Option A): May be useful later (to assess for anemia or leukopenia), but not the first step in evaluating disordered eating.

Thyroid function tests(Option B): Indicated if hyperthyroidism is suspected, but this patient's denial of underweight and behavior point more toward a psychiatric cause.

Serum potassium (Option C): Important if purging is suspected, but not the immediate step unless there's a history of vomiting or cardiac symptoms.
